entries.text: rt.perl.org has been upgraded! Here's a list of what's new and shiny.
entries.title: rt.cpan.org new features and upgrade to RT 4.0.11

entries.text: brian d foy launched a Crowdtilt campaign to fund the development of Pinto (and by ricochet Stratopan). We could probably wax poetically about the usefulness of Pinto, the shininess of Stratopan and the awesomeness of Jeff Thalhammer but, really, I think it could all be summarized by "shut up and take my money!".
entries.title: Crowd-funding Pinto

entries.text: A new version of Catalyst is on CPAN, with improvements both touching the code and the project itself. John Napiorkowski walks us through them.
entries.title: New Catalyst Release and Zombie-Boomstick Retrospective

entries.text: Adzuna is a London startup running on Perl. And, as we can see, they are doing quite well. Quite well indeed.
entries.title: Perl startup powering Dashboard at Downing Street, expanding internationally

entries.text: For a developer, it's all bugs. Well, it ain't, Ovid points out: there is bugs, and then there is unforeseen behaviors. And while the first group is almost always bad news, the second group can be... surprising.
entries.title: How to be agile without testing

entries.text: There's a new Devel::NYTProf in town, and boy does it look HOT.
entries.title: NYTProf v5 â€“ Flaming Precision

entries.text: Inspired by the Pinto Crowdtilt initiative, Yanick plays around with a way to aggregate all CPAN authors part of a machine's stack, and feed the result to the micro-donation web service Flattr.
entries.title: Flattr your CPAN Stack

entries.text: How do they deal with configuration file management at Booking.com? This is how.
entries.title: Dotfiles distribution

entries.text: How hard is it to extract all the regular expressions within a Perl project? Thanks to PPI and Peter Makholm's skills, much less than you would think.
entries.title: Reviewing my own regular expressions

entries.text: Peteris Krumins pushed a bunch of utility scripts to GitHub. We bet some of them could also be useful to you.
entries.title: I published another 10 of my projects to GitHub

entries.text: tinita shows us how to monitor and graph the request durations of a web application via munin and a crafty little perl script (natch).
entries.title: Keeping an eye on request duration

entries.text: For once, the title is not a rethorical question. domm walks us through the problem he has, and tries to figure out if Bread::Board is the solution he is looking for.
entries.title: Is Bread::Board the right tool for this job?

entries.text: Reini Urban gives us an update on p2, the new perl11 VM. ... wait, did I just said "Perl 11"?
entries.title: parser updates

chapters.title: Events
chapters.header: I usually list the next 3-4 events here. The list of all the events can be found on the web site. If your Perl event is not listed there, please let me know.
